00011 /**
00012  * @file
00013  *
00014  * Documentation source for Packet Input Block (PKI).
00015  */
00016 
00017 /**
00018 
00019 @ingroup cn78xx_native CN7XXX PKI
00020 
00021 This is a guide on how to configure PKI block for Cavium CN78XX, CN73XX
00022 and CNF75XX chips, which are referred as CN7XXX throughout this document.
00023 
00024 @section pki_backward_compatibility
00025 
00026 PKI can be broken down in 7 major areas, where backward compatibilty needs to be addressed
00027 
00028 @ref pki_if_cfg
00029 @ref wqe_and_pb_pools
00030 @ref wqe_fields
00031 @ref tag_fields
00032 @ref qos_and_queue_prio
00033 @ref pkt_sched
00034 @ref cluster_cfg
00035 @ref pki_red_and_bp
00036 @ref pki_cfg
00037 
00038 @subsection pki_if_cfg Interface/Port Configuration
00039     Software in previous chips controls the per port (interface/index) configuration for packet input block through
00040         provisioning the pkind registers. In CN7XXX port configuration is controlled via style registers.
00041     pkind configuration registers only control few aspect of port. To configure the port, a style needs to be
00042     assigned to the port first and after that confiuration can be controlled through that style register.
00043 
00044       To keep backward compatibility, SE library by default assigns style = pkind for that port.
00045       "cvmx_pip_config_port" supports the backward compatibility for many field. Some field that are not supported are qos
00046            and group watchers, portadd_en and different tagging mechanism for differnt protocols.
00047 
00048 
00049 @subsection wqe_and_pb_pools WQE and packet buffer pools
00050     In older chips wqe and packet data could reside in separate pools. Packet data buffers were hardwired to come from pool 0.
00051     CN7XXX Support-- CN7XXX has concept of auras and any aura can be assigned to buffer the packet data.
00052 
00053       To keep backward compatibilty all the packet data from all interface/ports are still buffered in aura0.
00054       By default SDK supports NO_WPTR mode where wqe entry uses same buffer as packet data and is appended
00055            to first packet buffer.
00056     Older chips supported 2 mode for packet buffering.
00057 
00058     a) WQE and packet data reside in different buffers which comes from different fpa pools. wqe buffers contains wqe descriptor
00059            and 12 words of packet data.
00060            CN7XXX support --- In CN7XXX this mode to keep wqe entry and packet data in different buffers can be chose by calling api "cvmx_helper_pki_set_wqe_mode"
00061            Note that buffers for wqe still comes from the same packet pool. There is no need to configure WQE buffer pool.
00062            You may want to increase the size of packet pool since now wqe buffers comes from there. Take note that this
00063            may increase the memory footprint.
00064            Also WQE buffer only contains first few words 5-8 depending on wqe_heder_size chosen in configuration.
00065            If application need first few words of packet data to be in WQE, they will need to copy it themselves.
00066            Also notice that WQE entry now has minimum of 5 words compare to 4 words before.
00067 
00068     b) WQE_NOPTR: WQE and packet data shares the same buffer, where 4 WQE WORDS are appended in front of packet data.
00069        CN7XXX support -- This is default mode in CN7XXX where wqe is appended in front of first packet data buffer.
00070                CN7XXX has minimum 5 words and there is a word after that for next_ptr field for linked buffers.
00071                next_ptr field is there even for packets which needs only 1 buffer.
00072 
00073 
00074 @subsection wqe_fields WQE fields
00075     WQE structure has been almost completely modified in CN7XXX. If software is accessing the fields of it directly,
00076         it needs to modify the code to use accessor functions.
00077     unused fields are not supported,
00078 
00079 
00080 @subsection tag_fields tag fields
00081 
00082 @subsection pkt_sched packet scheduling
00083     In older chips by default SE software sends packets to 8 differnet qos queues. There are no separate qos queues in CN7XXX,
00084         sso groups can be used as qos queues within.
00085         CN7XXX support-- In backward compatible mode by default all packets from all interfaces/ports go to sso group 0.
00086 
00087 @subsection qos_and_queue_prio OQS and QUEUE PRIORITIES
00088         In older chips sso could prioritize scheduling of work based on QOS queues0-7, in CN7XXX prioritization is based on groups.
00089         Each group can be prioritize betwee priorities 0-7. CN78XX has 256 groups which are configured in software, so that lowest 3
00090         bit of group denotes priority and remaining 5 bits represent a group which limits group numbers to 32 in backward
00091         compatible mode.
00092         68xx had many ways to configure QoS which are outlined below
00093                 1) per port QoS queue and group --
00094                         It could be configured through PIP_PRT_CFGX register by calling API
00095                         cvmx_pip_config_port() which now have support for CN7XXX
00096                 2) QoS watchers
00097                         software will reserve pcam entries 0-7 for qos watcher 0-7.In CN7XXX qos is controlled
00098                         via sso groups so there is no separate control for qos.
00099                 3) priority table
00100                         user need to config qpg table where grp = grp << 3 | qos, padd, bpid per port/channel are not supported in
00101                         backward compatible mode. user need to setup qpg_base by calling cvmx_pki_write_style_cfg
00102                 4) bit selector
00103                         can be achieved by programming pcam entries
00104 
00105 @subsection pki_red_and_bp PKI RED and backpressure
00106    RED is applied per aura, since in backward compatible mode all the packets to to aura 0
00107    RED can't be applied on per port/interface basis.
00108    Back Pressure- There are no per port back pressure counters in CN7XXX, back pressure is applied per aura.
00109                    Since all the packets goes to same aura in backward compatible mode, backpressure can't be applied
00110                    on per interface/port.
00111 
00112 
00113 @section new_apis Using PKI New APIS for CN7XXX
00114 
00115 @subsection pki_cfg Steps to configure PKI
00116 On power on PKI is initialized to default parameters which comes from cvmx-config.h/cvmx-executive.h
00117 by software which assigns packet pool 0, sso group 0 for all incoming packets
00118    and 1:1 pkind:style mapping. It then enables PKI to send/receive traffic.
00119         - To modify default parameters call
00120                 cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_pool(int node, int pool, int buffer_size, int buffer_count)
00121                 cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_aura(int node, int aura, int pool, int buffer_count)
00122                 cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_pool_buffer(int node, int buffer_count)
00123                 cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_aura_buffer(int node, int buffer_count)
00124                 cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_pkind_map(int node, int pkind, int style)
00125                 cvmx_helper_pki_get_dflt_style(int node, struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00126                 cvmx_helper_pki_set_dflt_style(int node, struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00127 
00128 If application wants to not use default initialization follow steps below--
00129 1) To disable PKI default initialization (it still will use default style parameters if none are provided by software) call
00130                    cvmx_helper_pki_no_dflt_init(int node)
00131 
00132 2) Configure/Modify PKI global parameters(if needed) by calling
00133         cvmx_pki_read_global_config(int node, struct cvmx_pki_global_config *gbl_cfg)
00134         cvmx_pki_write_global_config(int node, struct cvmx_pki_global_config *gbl_cfg)
00135         struct cvmx_pki_global_config conatins all PKI global parameters which can be modified.
00136 
00137 3) Configure scheduling resources(aura, sso groups etc) of interface/ports by calling api
00138         cvmx_helper_pki_init_interface(const int xiface, struct cvmx_pki_intf_schd *intfsch, struct cvmx_pki_global_schd *gblsch)
00139         OR
00140         cvmx_helper_pki_init_port(int ipd_port, struct cvmx_pki_prt_schd *prtsch)
00141     follow the code/example in examples/passthrough_o3/passthrough-pktio.c
00142 
00143 4) Modify port related parameter (If needed)) by calling
00144         cvmx_pki_get_port_config(int ipd_port, struct cvmx_pki_port_config *port_cfg)
00145         cvmx_pki_set_port_config(int ipd_port, struct cvmx_pki_port_config *port_cfg)
00146         If only flow profile realted parameters need to be modified and many ports are sharing same profile,
00147         parameters can be modified by calling
00148                 cvmx_pki_read_style_config(int node, int style, uint64_t cluster_mask, struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00149                 cvmx_pki_read_style_config(int node, int style, uint64_t cluster_mask,struct cvmx_pki_style_config *style_cfg)
00150 
00151 5) Install pcam entries (If needed) by calling
00152         cvmx_helper_pki_install_pcam_entry(int node, uint64_t cluster_mask, struct cvmx_pki_pcam_input input, struct cvmx_pki_pcam_action action)
00153 
00154 6) Enable RED and/or backpressure (if needed)
00155         cvmx_helper_pki_map_aura_chl_bpid(int node, uint16_t aura, uint16_t bpid,
00156                                       uint16_t chl_map[], uint16_t chl_cnt)
00157 
00158         cvmx_helper_setup_aura_qos(int node, int aura, bool ena_red, bool ena_drop,
00159                                uint64_t pass_thresh, uint64_t drop_thresh, bool ena_bp, uint64_t bp_thresh)
00160         follow the code/example in examples/passthrough_o3/passthrough-pktio.c
00161 
00162 7) Enable PKI to start processing packets by calling
00163         cvmx_helper_pki_enable(int node)
00164 
00165 */
